column5: Among the other good ideas, I always pack JB Weld Quik. you would be surprised how often you or your buddies can use this.

Just going to add my 2 cents here.baby wipes (why do you think the TP companies are now introducing it for everyday use......because it is great and you don't have too worry about it getting wet)small floats on everything that is important and could fly out of the boat.Berts bee's lotionextra glasses (not being able to see is a real downer)a good pair of long nose pliers, with a cutter that can cut hooksepi pen, or something similara good camera, make the memories last a lifetime.

Some great time tested information already here. These are must haves for me:Durable, waterproof boat bag for these goodies (toilet paper and duct tape are useless unless dry)Baker 9" 'Hookouts'Velcro wire wraps (reusable and works in water)

A Thermocell or two. A tow rope, a compass for the boat and a good flashlight. If taking your own boat you must have a floating rope, a noisemaker of some kind, an anchor, and make sure your battery terminals are covered.

Two things that have worked for me the last few years. First, since we generally cast for pike and prob average between 50-60 a day I like to set up my "operating" area in the back of the boat. I take off about 90 percent of all fish caught in our boat. First year i think i lost four spreaders and two long handled fish unhookers!! Tried to buy floatable ones but still had to do tricks to reclaim them. Now i use those casino type stretchy bungy cords and everything gets attached to the boat in a very handy way. Havent lost one since and my dad says im the best pike oral surgeon there is!!! 2nd is as simple as cornhuskers lotion. Does wonders on the tons of small knicks and tooth gashes i get each year, hey and it smells good!! Good luck

It sounds like you are taking your own boat. I like a prop nut wrench, spare cotter pins, and a spare prop with me. I keep some extra trailer light bulbs and fuses in the boat also. A few good lengths of rope is good to stow somewhere on board. Take a wire style bottom bouncer regardless of if you use them to fish; they can clear a clog on any outboard motors tell-tale. X2 on zip ties, electrical tape, multi-tool, and headlamp.
That sounds like a great idea...thanks! I've lost two pairs of long nosed pliers thanks to hammer handle pike...may just have to do that.
I use the fish culling floats that they sell at bass pro I attach them to my pliers and ipiolt remote.
I've been burnt too many times too and Sun Screen is a must for everyone. Don't leave home without it.
All great tips. I would agree that my top list includes duct tape, sunscreen, extra knife, garbage bags, and ziplock freezer bags of assorted sizes always come in handy for many different things.
Liquid bandage. Between fish teeth, fins, hooks and super lines, I'd like a tub big enough to stick your whole hand in before the week is through.

Some great ideas fellas.Not sure if this has been posted or not...but I always bring a couple strips (maybe 8X14") of thin close celled foam. I bought a cheap camp mattress a few years back and cut off a strip when I need it.On my fly in's I attach the foam to the inside of the boat with heavy duty 2-way tape and use it to hang all my go-to baits safely out of the way and within easy reach. It's also great for drying out bucktails before they go back in.

I always have some replacement rod tips along with piece of piano wire ~3/32" diameter, 5 minute epoxy and some thread. We always manage to break a pole or two and although that pole will never be the same it can at least be a functional backup. If the break is back a ways from the tip I slip the piano wire inside, slide the two pieces back together, wrap the joint with thread and then epoxy up the whole mess.
Little solar lights to put by outhouse or on Deck... this year trying a little LED spot light that lasts all night long

This may go without saying but I've been burned too many times with things going wrong on trips....electrical stuff for the boat. Multimeter, fuses, crimpers, spare trolling motor plug, wire nuts, electrical tape, contact cleaner, etc. On all my trips to Canada only once did it go without any real problems, and usually it was electrical.
Superglue always comes in handy for something and works great for cuts on the hands
[QUOTE=Draco1206;2792753]Baby wipes. A couple days of fried food and you'll know why. [/QUOTE} I think that's called maintenance of the lower unit. :-) Wipes are also good for wiping off repellent.
Sun gloves or jersey gloves with fingers cut off to keep the sun off the backs of your hands.
This year, I added a cut proof fileting glove, as I'm clumsy, and on blood thinners.
[QUOTE=Draco1206;2792753]Baby wipes. A couple days of fried food and you'll know why......LOL, funny stuff!
My brother has a small bilge. Makes it so much easier after a nights rain than using a per bu...I mean a bailer.
Chapstick, O'keefs Working Hands lotion, and a good pair of wire cutters.
Eyeglass repair kit.... Super Glue Bactine for cuts Vaseline for hands....

We have a foodsaver vacuum sealer that we use for spare clothes. Put a sweatshirt in one and sweatpants and socks in another. If someone would fall in, there is always a dry set of clothes to put on. More important the farther you are from camp. 45min. trip would be tough in 40* air temps. if you are soaking wet. Doesn't take up much space when sealed and always dry.
Dental floss and a sewing needle
Lots of good ideas guys thanks for the help. I am going to get a head lamp from work for sure.
First aid kit. Blue tarp. rope. Just never know.

The Executioner Electric Fly Swatter and a fresh set of batteries. Would not leave home without it. You can buy it on Amazon, don't skimp buy the executioner not the one with out the protective layers.
An extra pair of prescription eyeglasses and an eyeglass strap. And a credit card which the credit card company knows I may use in Canada.
Floating fish gripperBattery powered fanPower bank for charging camera/smart phone/tablet batteriesSodaStream

I like to have a nice Coleman thermos. I drink coffee in the AM and fill this up for the PM. The Coleman thermos keeps my coffee hot for hours. Love a good hot cup of Joe around 730p for a slight pick me up!
This is for the outpost cabins. Keeps the backside fresh if you know what I mean
Mouse traps, rope for a clothes line, a small bottle of hand soap in the boat, also a good kitchen knife for the cabin. I bring a heating pad and a couple cold packs.
Duct tape, multi tool, 2x rain gear, 2x knives, TP/baby wipes, asparin, antibiotic spray.
Duct tape matches garbage bags batteries sunscreen sun glasses bug spray and a eppy pen?

The first thing I always make sure a new person brings up is a good rain suit. Not something you bought at wal mart or SAMs, but something that costs a little money. Take it from a person who has gone through a bunch of rain gear, a good rain suit can make or break a trip. Bug spray, Ben's 100% deet in the little orange bottle or off! Deep woods as high level deet as you can find. A hatchet and a lighter, building a campfire if it's cold and rainy can really lift the spirits especially if you have kids or the fish have stuck their noses in the mud as my dad always says.
zip ties....good for fixing a torn netduct tape, electrical tape.multitool. bungees, Velcro.

Baby wipes. A couple days of fried food and you'll know why. I bought a new tool this year called the "fish claw". Tried it out on a small pike yesterday and it works great. Helps you grip the fish when you fillet it. Also was excellent for scaling perch and bluegills I caught. Scales came off like butter and didn't fly all over. Sold at BPS for $10, worth it.
Baby wipes > TP
Bourbon

We tend to do a fair amount of trolling. I bought this several years ago and it works great. You don't have to hold onto that rod the whole time and it keeps at least one rod out of the boat and out of the way when you aren't using it for trolling. I wouldn't make my trip without it anymore. We also bring a portable fish finder, invaluable for finding depths and underwter structure. Using a depth/ fish finder can mean the difference between cathcing and fishing. http://www.cabelas.com/product/Tite-...h-All+Products
Head Lamp - so you're able to have your hands free yet see what you're working on. Knife Sharpener - keep the edge on the blade. Cut-proof glove for the new guy that's learning to clean fish.
ice cube trays
:funnypost : GOOD ONE!

What are some of the gadgets or just little handy things you take to an outpost trip that make life easier or more convient? Maybe things that most people would over look when making a trip to the middle of nowhere. I am leaving a week from Friday and want to make sure I don't leave anything out. I want to make sure my boat is stocked and ready for anything we might face up there. Our trip is a boat in outpost cabin and the nearest small town is about 80 miles away.
Satellite phone. It will give you a sense of saftey. Rental units are relatively cheap.
Never really thought about the phone. I have been putting together a tool kit and making sure I have spare everything.

Lip grabber. Makes unhooking a walleye super easy. I just grab their lip in the water, lift em up to the edge of the boat and unhook em. No damage to the fish and they just hang there without wigglin'.
Zip ties are always a handy thing to have. Matches and small candle in a zip lock bag for just in case.
blow up doll......for extra floatation.

I've never used one of the expensive ones (Boga) and they may have some special value, but I've never been let down by my $20.00 BassPro Grip Master. It really makes landing toothy walleye's and northern's easy, quick, and almost harmless. I prefer it to a net.
what size?
Toilet paper in a sealed ziplock bag for emergencies.
I believe the proper term is " Code Brown"
